comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
That laughing lady better watch out, or she'll be bundled off to a Magdalene Laundry for being too happy.
Hard to date those cars in the distance, but maybe about 1910?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Edward J Bourke, Draper is in the 1911 census www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003311689/ There's a Denis D Bourke in the 1901 census William MacCurtin (sic), Hardware Merchant is in the 1911 census www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003311673/ and in the 1901 census as McCurtin. EDIT: Actually that Edward J Bourke could be Edward T Bourke - the hand writing is a bit unclear

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: There's a real wild west feel to those barrels and tea-chests with the horse and carriage passing by :-)

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The brick building that now houses Elvery's was not built at the time of this photo and it looks like there might be a year of construction at the top of the front facade if I could only read it. maps.google.ie/maps?q=castle+street+nenagh&hl=en&...

comment._content: The NIAH dates Elverys to 1923.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If the second car back is an A40 then it's post 1907, and the model T makes it post 1908. If, on the other hand, the second one is an A20 or a 12/4 it's sometime in the early '20s.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Hub gears available on bikes from about 1903, so no help there.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Kevin notes: Are these shoes? on the right - yes, I see a sign for Tylers, so that's a shoe shop.

And unless my streetviewing is well off, it is still a shoe shop today, called (imaginatively): Shoe Shop.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Sign at left for Dye Works:

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Notable absence of any members of the constabulary. I'd say this is pre-War of Independence & Civil War and it looks somehow too prosperous to be during the war years. I'd say 1910 give or take a couple of years is about right.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] The Thomson's Dye Works sign was previously seen in Duelling Dye Works

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: The Gas Lamps of Nenagh were installed in 1877. Some other great stories from Tipperary at that link too. Anne Kennedy, a vicious looking virago was brought up, charged with a breach of the Workhouse rules. She was a pauper nurse in one of the infirmary wards, and conducted herself a few night ago in such a disorderly manner, that the patients got into such a state of nervousness that they did not sleep during the night.... When a man charged at Nenagh Court with being drunk and incapable asked the Judge, "When is a man supposed to be drunk". Justice de Bura said, "there is a definition of drunkenness, if you lie on the ground without falling off.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] There's a great bit in Churchill Dunn's book about a popular scottish soldier up on a charge of being drunk and disorderly who was acquitted on the grounds that he was "not drunk as the term is commonly understood in Scotland."
